title: Python Live Book
text:
Preface
This is a Quarto book.
To learn more about Quarto books visit https://quarto.org/docs/books.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.1 Expressions Recap looking at variables
We will use JupyterLab or Google Colab to work through examples and discussions throughout the lectures and lab periods. They are a wonderful resource, with the benefit of not requiring you to install any specific distribution of Python, or any specific libraries.
This is a book created from markdown and executable code.
• A line of code generally contains a statement
• Statements indicate the task that we want the computer to perform
x = 2
This is a recommended programming style for Python: PEP8 Style Guide

title: 1  Introduction
text:
x is termed an identifier of a variable
= is the assignment symbol
2 is an integer that we are assigning to the variable identified by ‘x’














Note the spaces around operators and the assignment symbol

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.2 Variable Names

Case-sensitive!








variable names may contain letters, digits, and underscores
cannot begin with a number

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.3 Data Types

Every variable has a type
Python makes it easy to discover the type of variables with the built-in command type













type is a function whose argument is y and whose output is float.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.4 Arithmetic Operations
The division operator / always returns a float, even if the operands are integers. The floor division operator // returns the integer part of the division result. The modulus operator % gives the remainder after division. Python follows the PEMDAS order of operations (Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication and Division, Addition and Subtraction).
























x raised to the power of y






The integer floor operation






The modulus (remainder) operation







1.4.1 Operator precedence rules

Parentheses evaluate first – If nested, innermost parentheses evaluate first
Exponents evaluate next, in order of right-to-left
Multiplication, division, and modulus evaluate next, in order of left-to-right
Addition and subtraction evaluate last, in order of left-to-right















1.4.2 Use parentheses to avoid ambiguity

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.5 Strings Intro

The string type holds sequence of characters
The print function displays strings on the screen
The f-string stands for formatted string literals, a more readable way to include variables in strings







Strings can span multiple lines via escape characters






Basic f-string example

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.6 Obtaining user input

The input function allows the user to supply a value
The resulting value is always a string

name = input("Please enter your name: ")
print(f"You name is {name}!")

Note: While the rest of this site runs Python using Pyodide, browser-based environments like Quarto don’t support input() for user interaction. To demonstrate interactive input, we use Trinket.io, which allows users to type responses during program execution.



This code block prompts the user to enter their name and then prints a greeting message.The input function is used to get user input, and the or “Guest” part ensures that if the user doesn’t enter anything, the default name “Guest” is used.
name = input("Enter your name: ") or "Guest"
# The f-string is used to format the greeting message with the user's name.
print(f"Hello, {name}!")

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.7 Casting data types via int
y = input("Please enter your age")
z = int(y)
print(f"The variable z is {z}, which is of data type: {type(z)}")

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.8 Boolean expressions
Boolean expressions evaluate to keywords True or False:

greater than: >
less than: <
greater than or equal to: >=
less than or equal to: <=
is equal to: ==
is not equal to: !=

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.9 Conditional execution: if statement
The if statement allows your program’s execution to depend on the state of the program

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.10 Comments

Comments allow you to document your code inline
Documentation allows others to understand the purpose of different sections of your program
Comments are indicated with the # symbol, and can appear above or to the right of your code

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.11 Variables, values, and types

Variables refer to objects
Objects have both a value and a type
In the expression x = 78, x is a variable whose value is 78 and whose type is int














1.11.1 Dynamic typing
Python determines your variable’s types during program execution

title: 2  Control statements and program development
text:
2.1 Objectives
In this module, you’ll learn:
crumbs: 2  Control statements and program development

title: 2  Control statements and program development
text:
Decide whether to execute actions with conditional statements if, if ... else and if -> elif -> else
Execute statements repeatedly with for and while.
Shorten assignment expressions with augmented assignments.
Use the for statement and the built-in range function to repeat actions for a sequence of values.
Perform sentinel-controlled repetition with while.
Learn problem-solving skills: understanding problem requirements, dividing problems into smaller pieces, developing algorithms to solve problems and implementing those algorithms in code.
Develop algorithms through the process of top-down, step-by-step refinement.
Create compound conditions with the Boolean operators and, or and not .
Stop looping with break statements.
Force the next iteration of a loop with continue .
Use some functional-style programming features to write scripts that are more concise, clearer, easier to debug and easier to parallelize
crumbs: 2  Control statements and program development

title: 2  Control statements and program development
text:
2.2 Control statements

Computer programs execute sequentially
Control statements are able to alter the sequence of executions
crumbs: 2  Control statements and program development

title: 2  Control statements and program development
text:
2.3 Selection statements

if
if else
if elif else



An example of the if elif else block:
crumbs: 2  Control statements and program development

title: 2  Control statements and program development
text:
2.4 Conditional Expressions

2.4.1 Expressions evaluate to either True or False

Non-zero numbers evaluate to True
Non-empty strings evaluate to True















2.4.2 Suite indentation

The block under each condition is termed a suite
Python relies on proper indentation for its syntax









2.4.3 Conditional expressions may be written in one line of code

title: 3  Summary
text: In summary, this book has no content whatsoever.

title: 2  Control statements and program development
text:
2.5 Loops with the while statement

The while command allows a block of code to be executed a variable number of times


2.5.1 Determine when a Netflix subscription will exceed $20

Let’s assume that Netflix will raise the price by 5% after every year
